These phenomena in- clude increased temperature trends (global warming), sea level rises, ice mass losses, and extreme weather events. Decent work/jobs: Decent work involves op- portunities for work that is productive and provides a fair income, security in the work- place and social protection for families, free- dom for workers to participate in the decisions that affect them, and equality for women and men. Green businesses should provide decent, green jobs. Environmental protection: Environmental pro- tection is a practice of protecting the natural environment on individual, organisational or governmental levels, for the benefit of both the environment and humans. It aims to conserve natural resources, preserve the current state of the environment and to reverse its degradation where possible. Fossil fuels: Fossil fuels are fuels such as coal, crude oil, and natural gas that were formed from the buried remains of plants and animals that lived millions of years ago. They are con- sidered to be harmful to the environment be- cause their use creates greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide or methane which cause global warming. Global warming: Global warming refers to the increase in temperature across the Earth due to the increase in greenhouse gas emissions resulting from the burning of fossil fuels. Green business: A green business is a busi- ness that produces/provides an environmen- tally friendly product/service or uses an envi- ronmentally friendly process, or both. Green businesses thus help to protect and restore the environment, while generating profit for the owner. Greenhouse effect: The greenhouse effect is a natural process that warms the Earth’s sur- face. When energy from the sun reaches the Earth’s atmosphere, greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide act like a roof, absorbing and re-radiating some of this warmth. This is a vital, natural process that allows life on Earth to exist. However, because human ac- tivities such as the burning of fossil fuels in- crease the concentration of these gases, we are now facing a problem of global warming. Greenhouse gases: Greenhouse gases are gases such as carbon dioxide or methane that trap heat and make the planet warmer. A large share of these gases are produced through hu- man activities such as the burning of fossil fu- els for electricity or for transport, for example. Green jobs: Green jobs are decent jobs that contribute to preserving or restoring the en- vironment. Green jobs can be found in tradi- tional sectors such as manufacturing and con- struction, or in new, emerging green sectors such as renewable energy and energy efficien- cy. Green businesses are essential providers of green jobs. Pollution: Pollution is the introduction of un- safe or toxic substances that are harmful for living organisms into the environment (the soil, the air and water). Pollution is caused by human activities, such as the spilling of oil, the emission of harmful gases from cars or fac- tories, or the disposal of industrial waste. Renewable resources: Renewable resources are resources that can be replenished naturally, usually in a short period of time. For example, solar energy is a renewable energy source be- cause it replenishes naturally in a short period of time, while crude oil, natural gas, coal and uranium (nuclear energy) are non-renewable sources of energy as they do not form or re- plenish naturally in a short period of time. 3 R: This is a strategy for dealing with waste, involving reducing consumption before waste is generated in the first place; reusing rather than throwing away items for which new uses can be found; and recycling waste by extract- ing materials from it and transforming them into new products. Below is a streamlined version of the “Business Efficiency Workbook” that gradually evolves into a “baby ERP” for startups. It integrates core strategic thinking with practical, operational tracking—and it includes clear ROI measures for greening (and efficiency) initiatives without duplicating the full financial model.

System Overview
Purpose:
To create a single, evolving workbook that helps startups:

Define their vision, strategy, and ESG/intention (via a dedicated Vision & Intent tab)
Develop a Business Model Canvas (BMC) as a strategic blueprint (BMC Overview)
Track daily/weekly operations and resource efficiency (Ops & Resource Efficiency)
Log improvement initiatives—including greening measures with cost, timeline, responsibility, and ROI (Improvement Log & Greening Plan)
Review performance via a consolidated dashboard that shows key KPIs and ROI on efficiency/greening initiatives (Performance Dashboard)
How It Works:

Vision & Intent Tab:

Captures the startup’s mission, core values, and any ESG or climate resilience goals.
Updated at the start and at major strategic milestones.
BMC Overview Tab:

Provides the 9–block strategic blueprint (Key Partners, Activities, Resources, Value Proposition, etc.).
Serves as a high-level reference for ensuring that daily actions support the overall business model.
Updated periodically (e.g., once a month or upon strategic pivots).
Ops & Resource Efficiency Tab:

Tracks daily or weekly operational metrics (e.g., resource usage, process performance).
Captures environmental or “greening” measures subtly—for example, energy usage per unit or waste reduction.
Updated on a weekly basis.
Improvement Log & Greening Plan Tab:

Lists operational improvement initiatives (including those that boost efficiency and “green” performance).
Each improvement record includes: description, timeline (“When”), responsible person (“Who”), cost, financing method, and estimated ROI.
Acts as an actionable checklist that drives day‐to‐day improvements.
Performance Dashboard Tab:

Provides a consolidated, visual summary of key KPIs (such as operating margins, resource efficiency ratios, and ROI on efficiency/greening improvements).
Used for monthly or quarterly reviews to inform decision‐making and strategic adjustments.
Progressive Development & Module Integration Flow
Startups in the accelerator meet twice a week. Each module triggers updates in the workbook along one of four ERP Flow Steps:

Data Input / Baseline:

Early modules (Design Thinking, User Research, The Survey)
Capture vision, initial assumptions, and baseline resource/market data in the Vision & Intent and BMC Overview tabs.
Analysis / Prioritization:

Mid modules (Market Research, Reframe, Ideation)
Analyze collected data to identify key opportunities—including “greening” opportunities—and rank potential improvements.
Update the BMC Overview (e.g., refine Value Proposition and Key Resources) and note preliminary improvement ideas.
Implementation / Action:

Modules such as Prototyping, Test & Iterate, Project Management, and Cost Model
Enter specific improvement initiatives (with associated ROI estimates) in the Improvement Log & Greening Plan tab.
Update daily operations in the Ops & Resource Efficiency tab as changes are implemented.
Review / Update:

Later modules (Pitch, Service Design, Continuous Innovation, Risk Management)
Use the Performance Dashboard to review progress, compare current results against targets, and update the Vision & Intent or BMC Overview if needed.
Reflect on the ROI and impact of greening measures, ensuring that operational improvements continue to support overall strategy.
Pros & Cons of Including the BMC in the Same Document
Pros:

Centralized Strategic View:
Integrating the BMC keeps all strategic information in one place, ensuring every operational update can be traced back to the overall business model.

Enhanced Alignment:
With the BMC as a reference, teams can immediately see how operational and greening initiatives (logged in the Improvement Log) support key elements like Value Proposition, Cost Structure, and Key Resources.

Simplified Updates:
Changes in strategy—whether driven by market feedback or internal performance—can be recorded in the BMC Overview and then quickly reflected in operational areas, promoting an integrated approach.

Cons:

Potential Complexity:
Merging qualitative strategic planning (BMC) with quantitative operational tracking might overwhelm users if not clearly organized.

Redundancy Risks:
Some information (e.g., key resource needs or cost drivers) might be repeated in both the BMC and the Ops/Improvement sections, potentially leading to confusion.

Different Update Frequencies:
The BMC is generally updated less frequently than daily operational data. Mixing them in one workbook might require clear guidelines to avoid conflicts.

Decision:
Include the BMC as its own clearly labeled tab (“BMC Overview”) within the workbook. This tab acts as the strategic “north star” that is referenced by and linked to the operational and improvement sections. Updates to the BMC occur on a periodic (e.g., monthly) or milestone basis, separate from the more frequent operational data updates.

Updated System Description & Module Flow
Business Efficiency Workbook – Overview:

Vision & Intent:
Sets the mission, core values, and ESG/climate resilience goals. (Initial setup and periodic reviews.)

BMC Overview:
Captures the strategic blueprint (Business Model Canvas). It helps align all operational improvements with the startup’s overall strategy. (Updated periodically.)

Ops & Resource Efficiency:
Monitors daily/weekly operational metrics and greening measures (e.g., energy usage, waste reduction). (Updated weekly.)

Improvement Log & Greening Plan:
Logs improvement initiatives with clear ROI measures. Each entry details the greening measure, when it will be done, who will do it, how much it costs, financing options, and ROI. (Updated as new initiatives arise, typically during the mid to later modules.)

Performance Dashboard:
Provides a snapshot of key performance indicators (including ROI on greening measures), enabling a monthly or quarterly review of progress. (Used during the review phase.)

Module Flow (32 Modules – Key Integration Points):

Part I. Ignite (Pre-Incubator):

Modules 1–4 (Design Thinking, User Research, The Survey, Market Research):
→ ERP Flow Step: Data Input / Baseline
→ Relevant Tabs: Vision & Intent; BMC Overview
→ Action: Capture initial mission, strategic assumptions, and baseline metrics.
Module 5 (Reframe) & Module 6 (Creativity & Ideation):
→ ERP Flow Step: Analysis / Prioritization

Modules 7–10 (The Pitch, Your Brand, and early Incubator Modules like Introduction & Goal Setting, Intro to UX):
→ ERP Flow Step: Implementation / Action

Modules 11–16 (BMC, Prototyping, Test & Iterate, Revenue Model, UX Design, Project Management, Cost Model, Balance Sheet):
→ ERP Flow Step: Continued Implementation / Action

Modules 17–32 (Service Design, Pitch Recap, UI, Graphic Design & Communications, Continuous Innovation, Record Keeping, Leadership, Personal Brand, Marketing Strategy, Hiring, Organizational Gaps, Sales, Business Plan, Manager, Supply Chain, Negotiation, Ethics, Communication, Financing, Risk, Investment, Mindsets):

As each module (delivered twice a week) is completed, the workbook is updated in the relevant tab(s) based on the ERP Flow Step:

Baseline & Data Input in early modules
Analysis & Prioritization mid-way
Implementation & Action as projects are launched
Review & Update in later modules, tying together strategic and operational changes
Summary
The Business Efficiency Workbook is a unified, evolving system that:

Begins with a clear vision and mission (Vision & Intent)
Uses the BMC Overview as a strategic backbone—updated periodically to reflect changing assumptions and opportunities
Tracks daily operations and environmental efficiency in the Ops & Resource Efficiency tab
Captures specific improvement initiatives (including greening measures with ROI) in the Improvement Log & Greening Plan
Summarizes progress and ROI on both business and sustainability fronts in the Performance Dashboard
Each module in the accelerator (32 modules, delivered twice a week) “triggers” updates in the workbook through one of four ERP Flow Steps: Data Input, Analysis, Implementation, and Review. This approach ensures that as the program progresses, the startup’s system evolves from initial planning to a fully integrated “baby ERP” that balances business efficiency with meaningful ESG and climate resilience outcomes.
